As for saying that there are differences in kind,
it means that when dharmas revolve through time,
there are differences in kind, not differences in substance.
For example, when a gold vessel is destroyed and made into other things, although the shape is different, the color is not different.
Also, when milk and so forth transform into curd and so forth, the taste, potency, and other qualities are abandoned, but the color is not abandoned.
In the same way, when dharmas go from the future time to the present time,
although they abandon the kind of the future and obtain the kind of the present,
the substance of those dharmas is neither obtained nor abandoned.
Again, when they go from the present time to the past time,
Although the present class is abandoned and the past class is obtained,
yet the substance of that dharma is also neither obtained nor abandoned.
As for the explanation of the difference in characteristics,
it is said that when dharmas revolve through time,
there is a difference in characteristics, not a difference in substance.
Each dharma in the three times has the characteristics of the three times.
One characteristic is in direct combination, the other two characteristics are not separate.
Just as when a person is directly attached to the form of one woman,
he is not said to be free from attachment to the forms of other women.
In the same way, when dharmas abide in the past,
they are directly combined with the characteristic of the past,
and the other two characteristics are not said to be separate.
When they abide in the future,
they are directly combined with the characteristic of the future,
and the other two characteristics are not said to be separate.
When they abide in the present,
they are directly combined with the characteristic of the present,ğŸ”½and the other two characteristics are not said to be separate.
As for the explanation of the difference in states,
it is said that when dharmas revolve through time,
there is a difference in states, not a difference in substance.
It is like moving a single tally stick.
Placing it in the unit place is called one.
Placing it in the tens place is called ten.
Placing it in the hundreds place is called a hundred.
Although the positions it passes through are different, the substance of the tally stick is not different.
In the same way, all dharmas pass through the positions of the three time periods.
Although they obtain the three names, their substance is not different.
The time periods established by this master are not mixed up.
This is because the three time periods are distinguished based on function.
That is to say, conditioned dharmas that have not yet performed their function are called the future time period.
Those that are currently performing their function are called the present time period.
Those whose function has already ceased are called the past time period.
As for the explanation of depending on difference,
it is said that when dharmas revolve through the time periods, they are established as having different names based on their differences before and after.

It is like a single woman who is called a daughter when referring to her mother and is called a mother when referring to her daughter. Although her substance is not different, she obtains the names of daughter and mother based on the differences in reference.
In the same way, dharmas are called past when referring to what is later.
They are called future when referring to what is earlier.
They are called present when referring to both.
The time periods established by this master are mixed up.
Why is this?
Because in each of the three times there are the three times, in mutual relation of prior and posterior.
That is to say, the prior and posterior moments in the past are called past and future,
and the middle one is called present. The future and the present should be considered in the same way.
Although a present dharma is only one moment, it becomes three times because it is related to what follows, what precedes, and what is simultaneous.
How can this be correct?ğŸ”½If you say that the three times are established on the basis of differences in characteristics,
then there is also confusion, because each of the three times is said to have the characteristics of the three times.
If you say that the three times are established on the basis of differences in species,

then this is also unreasonable, because apart from the self-nature of dharmas, what else can be called a species?ğŸ”½If you say that the species of dharmas in the future becomes extinct when it arrives at the present,
and that the species of dharmas in the present is born when it arrives at the past,
then the past would have birth and the future would have extinction. How can this be correct?
Therefore the third explanation is the best, because it is possible for dharmas to have activity at the time.

When practitioners of contemplation give rise to realization, why do they also contemplate [suffering] as suffering?

From beginningless time, regarding all suffering, they have given rise to ignorance.

Furthermore, if a dharma is a skandha, is the cause of the skandhas, is the cessation of the skandhas, and is the antidote to the skandhas, it is established as a truth.
Because space and non-analytical cessation are neither aggregates, nor causes of aggregates, nor exhaustion of aggregates, nor antidotes to aggregates, they are not established as truths.
Furthermore, if a dharma is a disease, a cause of disease, an exhaustion of disease, or an antidote to disease, it is established as a truth.
Because space and non-analytical cessation are neither diseases, nor causes of diseases, nor exhaustions of diseases, nor antidotes to diseases, they are not established as truths.
Furthermore, if a dharma is a boil, an arrow, a calamity, a misfortune,

an antidote to boils, arrows, calamities, and misfortunes, it is established as a truth.
Because space and non-analytical cessation are none of those, they are not established as truths.
Furthermore, if a dharma is a heavy burden,
can bear a heavy burden, is an exhaustion of heavy burdens,

Because space and non-analytical cessation are none of those, they are not established as truths.
Furthermore, if a dharma is this shore, that shore, a river, or a boat, it is established as a truth.
Space and non-analytical cessation are not any of those, so they are not established as truths.
Furthermore, if a dharma is suffering, the cause of suffering,
the path, or the fruit of the path, it is established as a truth.
Space and non-analytical cessation are neither suffering nor the cause of suffering,
neither the path nor the fruit of the path, so they are not established as truths.
Furthermore, if a dharma has the nature of a cause or the nature of a result, it is established as a truth.
Space and non-analytical cessation have neither the nature of a cause nor the nature of a result, so they are not established as truths.
Furthermore, space and non-analytical cessation are not the truth of suffering or the truth of the origin because they are uncontaminated.
They are not the truth of cessation because they are indeterminate.
They are not the truth of the path because they are unconditioned.
Furthermore, space and non-analytical cessation do not fall into the world, so they are not the first three truths.

Space and non-analytical cessation are not the objects of wrong views and pure wisdom, so they are not established as truths.

Space and non-analytical cessation are not the objects of ignorance and wisdom.

Space and non-analytical cessation are neither defiled matters nor pure matters.
Therefore, they are not established as truths.
Furthermore, if a dharma is a matter of delight and a matter of disgust, it is established as a truth.
Space and non-analytical cessation are neither matters of delight nor matters of disgust.

Space and non-analytical cessation are not the objects of a delighted or disgusted mind.

Question: If the meaning of non-distortion is the meaning of truth,
then the four kinds of perversions should not be included in the truths.
Why is this?
Because they are perverted.
Answer: They are established as perversions due to other conditions.
They are included in the truths due to other conditions.
That is to say, they are established as perversions due to three conditions.
First, because of determination.
Second, because of increase.
Third, because of one-sided perversion.
Because they correspond to the characteristics of existence and reality, they are included in the truths.
Furthermore, because they take the impermanent to be permanent, suffering to be happiness, the impure to be pure, and non-self to be self, they are established as perversions.
Because they have the nature of causes and effects, they are included in the truths.
Question: If the meaning of non-deception is the meaning of truth,
All false speech should not be included in the category of truths.
Why is this?
Because it is deceptive.
The answer is: False speech is established due to other conditions.
That is to say, it contradicts one's own thoughts and deceives others.
It is included in the category of truths due to other conditions.
That is to say, it exists and is real, corresponding to the characteristics of reality.
Furthermore, false speech is established due to other conditions.
That is to say, not seeing and saying one has seen, seeing and saying one has not seen.
Not hearing and saying one has heard, hearing and saying one has not heard.
Not perceiving and saying one has perceived, perceiving and saying one has not perceived.
Not knowing and saying one knows, knowing and saying one does not know.
It is included in the category of truths due to other conditions.
That is to say, it has the nature of causes and effects, and therefore the true meaning is the meaning of truth.
